title: Craig Cerrig-Gleisiad a Fan Frynych Walking Route

images.title: Philip Halling / Fan Frynych
images.caption: The summit trig point on Fan Frynych with the Brecon Beacons in the distance.

images.title: Paul Thomas / Craig Cerrig-gleisiad from the cwm below Fan Frynych
images.caption: Craig Cerrig-gleisiad from the cwm below Fan Frynych

images.title: Oliver Dixon / Craig Cerrig Gleisiad
images.caption: Craig Cerrig Gleisiad. A National Nature Reserve, home to a rich variety of arctic-alpine flora.

images.title: Nigel Davies / Pool above Craig Cerrig Gleisiad
images.caption: Pool above Craig Cerrig Gleisiad. There are two pools marked in this square. This is the southernmost of them, visible as you walk the path along the rim of Craig Cerrig Gleisiad. This pool is larger and more open than the north one allowing birds to swoop low along it in search of insects.

images.title: Mick Garratt / Glyn Tarell From the Path up Craig Cerrig-gleisiad
images.caption: Glyn Tarell From the Path up Craig Cerrig-gleisiad

images.title: Alan Bowring / A view up the Nant Cwm-du
images.caption: A view up the Nant Cwm-du. The watercourse drops here over slabs of Old Red Sandstone.

images.title: Old workings on Fan Frynych by don cload, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Old workings on Fan Frynych

images.title: Jeremy Bolwell / The Beacons from Fan Frynych
images.caption: The Beacons from Fan Frynych. Pen y Fan Horseshoe Walk and Corn Du viewed from Fan Frynych across the Tarell valley.

description: Enjoy a walk through this spectacular glacial National Nature Reserve and climb to the summit of Fan Frynych on this challenging walk in the Brecon Beacons. The reserve can be easily accessed from a lay-by on the A470 from which the walk starts. Soon you will be exploring this wonderful natural amphitheatre with imposing craggy cliffs created during the Ice Age, 20000 years ago. The reserve contains rare arctic-alpine plants such as purple saxifrage and mossy saxifrage. There is also an abundance of wildlife to look out for including Peregrine falcons, merlin, red kite and a variety of butterflies. The area also contains woodland, streams and an Iron Age Hillfort.  From the 629 m (2,064 ft) summit of Fan Frynych there are splendid views over the national park. The Brecon Beacons Way also passes the reserve so you could pick this up to continue your walk.
